OK Folks. Time for me to take a break from the ongoing battle of politics.
 
 I've been training in Tae Kwon-Do (Korean for "The Way of the Foot and Hand) for about eight months now and am thouroughly enjoying it. I have already progressed through four belt ranks and will be participating in my sixth tournament later this month. I have a long term desire to open my own school when I become ready to do so.
 
 Just thought I'd share this with you since I have rarely posted here as of late.

OK Folks. Time for me to take a break from the ongoing battle of politics.
 
 I've been training in Tae Kwon-Do (Korean for "The Way of the Foot and Hand) for about eight months now and am thouroughly enjoying it. I have already progressed through four belt ranks and will be participating in my sixth tournament later this month. I have a long term desire to open my own school when I become ready to do so.
 
 Just thought I'd share this with you since I have rarely posted here as of late.

 I to train in Tae Kwon Do (thought it was the way of the foot and fist - nevermind, close enough). Have been for about 6 years.
 
 Have also trained in:
 Kung Fu (though not really long enough to be worth a serious mention).
 4 different styles of Karate (made it to 2nd kyu - 2 short of black belt)
 Ju Jitsu (graded 3 times if I remember correctly)
 
 For a while I did karate and tae kwon do together (different classes), but after my last karate grading (where I got hammered - but still passed) I started noticing that injuries weren't healing so fast.
 
 Should be going back to tae kwon do this week, but my right achilles is getting a bit old. Chances are, I'll go back (probably once week), hope all my bits hold out and keep it up for another year or so - maybe get another belt.
 
 I am currently Blue belt (red stripe), so a few more to get to black.
 
 Anyway, good luck in your martial arts career whereever it takes you. Mine has been going (on and off) for just over 20 years.
 
 Maybe time to have one last career change - Tai Chi emoticon_cool 
 
 Smiley

Cool! I have been training Pyong an Do Won Kung Fu for a little over a year now, and am a brown belt which is about the sixth belt (the 8th is black). This style of Kung Fu is almost all about street fighting, and not at all about sport. There is no tournaments or games in Kung Fu, because the moves that we are taught are so debilitating that they cannot be done to someone unless their life is in danger.
 
 I've been having a lot of fun and met some great people.

www.bullshido.com will serve you well.
 
 Comments like 
eight months... four belt ranks

 
 and especially 
There is no tournaments or games in Kung Fu, because the moves that we are taught are so debilitating that they cannot be done to someone unless their life is in danger.

 
 set off major alarm bells for me. 
 
 The comment about moves so dangerous they can't be used is truly scary. 
 
 I know you won't believe me, but the moves you've been taught, whatever they are, simply don't work as described. You certainly haven't seen them work as described, have you?
 
 I don't want to say your master is straight out lying to you, or at least grossly exaggerating the truth, but he almost certainly is. I hope you don't take offense to this comment, but I have seen this happen so many times.
 
 I currently do Muay Thai, I wish I had time to do more. I make no claims about it being "effective for the street" - if you want to survive "on the street", get better at running.

 Are we having fun yet?

 
 Real kung fu, or at least the type of kung fu we do, is not moving around with our hands up in the air making weird noises. Its also not Shaolin. Learning to use chi is very important, and can be devastating in combat. My master has demonstrated this. Once, he stood on one leg and had two strong men push him with all of their force. He didn't move at all, he didn't even lean. Another time, he bent steel rebar with his fingers. I saw it.

True, We learn not only forms, techniques, and sparring, we also learn real-life self defense that can be lethal. My SaBum-Nim has always drilled into my head that I should only use my self defenses as a last resort.

Symbiote

These moves being the gouging of someone's eyes, chopping of windpipes, breaking of necks, caving of knees, etc. Obviously I know these will work if done right. Its basic anatomy.

 
 At least these fall into the category of "impractical" or "impractical to train", unlike the more egregious category of "devastating" martial arts moves such as "pressure point strikes that can stop a man's heart" which are entirely mythical.
 
 
All I'm saying is, its probably unsportsmanlike in a sparring match to gouge the opponents eyes out.

 
 This is true. But if I put a BJJ fighter in a room against a professional eye gouger, and told them both to gouge each others eyes, I'd guarantee the BJJ guy would be better at doing it. Same with breaking someone's neck or arm or ankle. Similarly a kickboxer could break someone's knees better than a trained knee-stomper. Learning these techniques as a method of fighting just doesn't work unless you're up against someone you badly outmatch in the first place. It just doesn't make sense to me. A mediocre wrestler could bite the ear off a professional ear biter - I just don't get it.
 
 That and not only are these things unsportsmanlike in the ring, they're unsportsmanlike in the real world too - they'll really, really, #### people off. Try and gouge some guy's eyes out and don't be surprised that when you fail, he's going to stomp on your face when you're passed out.
 
 
PS: My master trains my city's police force.

 
 Why would the police want to learn deadly or debilitating moves like stomping someone's knee or gouging their eyes? They have guns don't they? Surely the whole point of going in to take someone down would be to subdue them without creating a law suit and a cripple?
 
 At least can you see the problem with making any real claim about a style which cannot be tested?
 
 http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yuki_Nakai
 
 This guy got eye gouged, beat the guy, won his next fight and then lost to royce gracie... yes his opponent was successful in causing permanent disfigurement.
 
 The last time someone attempted an eye gouge when he was being ground and pounded I'm aware of, the guy having his eye gouged bit the gouger's finger... I could certainly see it being effective from a dominant position, but then shouldn't you train to get that position, since the process of gouging an eye is fairly intuitive and doesn't really require training?

 Yes it does. Chi strength increases power to all moves if used properly.
 
 
 
its mainly useful for increasing the power of your eye gouges and neck breaks.

 
 I understand that you're skeptical, I was too. But you have to see it to believe it. I have seen very powerful strikes using chi, from skinny guys.
 
 I understand all of you think it is an eleborate trick, however keep in mind that the Grandmaster has trained for over 30 years in this style of kung fu. His master was trained by monks. He has also been recognized in many martial art magazines, and has received martial arts awards. And, as I said before, he trains my city's police force. I doubt a con artist would do that.

Wasn't Frank Dux on that Bullshido site?
 
 It says "Frank Dux Exposed and FAQ".
Frank Dux may be a lot of things but never doubt that he is a skilled martial artist. He really studied Ninjitsu and his schools stressed full contact sparring and all sorts of punishing routines one might expect from Ninjitsu. This I know first hand. We used to line up and as you reached the front of the line you turned and the student behind you would shove you off your feet with all their might. Backwards fall practice.
Shooterandproud

At my school, the class is very light until about red belt. We rarely use much contact. Its mostly training our strength and reflexes. Its pretty gentle, however the black belt class is not. Neither are the extra classes called ?Black Tigers? that are offered to black belts. Those classes are far from gentle.
 
 We also train a lot of forms and patterns in all of the classes.
Symbiote

We also train a lot of forms and patterns in all of the classes.

 
 Why does this not surprise me at all?
 
 As you progress to higher belt levels, are secret truths contained within earlier forms revealed?
 
 For example the "pearl necklace" form actually contains a secret defence against a roundhouse kick by ducking down and punching your opponent in his planted thigh?
Shooterandproud

Why does this not surprise me at all?
 
 As you progress to higher belt levels, are secret truths contained within earlier forms revealed?
 
 For example the "pearl necklace" form actually contains a secret defence against a roundhouse kick by ducking down and punching your opponent in his planted thigh?

 
 I believe they are evident when you first learn them, but to answer your question, yes. As we progress through the form, we learn what all of the moves are doing and such.
 
 We don't have a thing called the "pearl necklace" form. All of our forms are in Korean (maybe chinese). Some of them:
 
 Chul Ki Sam Dan
 No Pae
 Sip Soo
 Bon Wal
 Koryo
 Tang Kwon
 
 We also have things called "animal techniques", which are kind of like mini forms for defense against certain types of moves. They are usually from one to four moves. Some of them are certain types of blocking while punching, dodging, etc. Examples:
 
 Monkey
 Dragon
 Swallow
 Stork
 Tiger Tail
 Tiger Springs from Den
 Seek Needle
 Three Step Retreat
 Retreating Deception
 
 There are 72 of these. We must memorize all 72, plus 4 forms for brown belt (my rank). There are other requirements, of course. These are just some.

 Im 42 years old, a little overweight, a lot out of shape, and have a glass back do to an injury and surgery, I couldnt run if I had to, so I will stick to the pullsquezebang form of personal defense,lol.
Nebuchadnezzar

I know nothing of street fighting so please don't take my statements as such as I am only referring to sport-based grappling. I am only a mere white belt in Gracie BJJ (taught by a man named Art [brown belt at the time of my training who was taught by the Gracie family themselves] in Cypress/North Houston, Texas) so I profess no extensive knowledge in the art.
 
 When I was in boarding school, the wrestling coach caught wind of my interest and small amount training in BJJ. He used me to practice sparring with his wrestlers, and since I am allowed to do several moves that are illegal in a wrestling match and use leverage instead of force I could train with all of the weight classes.
 
 I'm not going to say that I won every session, that would be a lie, but his wrestlers were the best in our region and several of them got out of sticky situations rather easily sometimes. After the match, I'd congratulate them and comment about how they looked like they were done for, and they would tell me that anything is better than me trying to break their arm every five seconds.
 
 Oh, how I love rolling arm-bars.
